abstract: Controversy over bronze statues, cast from clay and wax sculptures created by Edgar Degas, is expected to continue even after their manufacturer, Valsuani foundry in France, is liquidated; pieces, which are sold as authentic Degas artworks by his heirs, are part of larger debate over posthumous reproductions.

headline.print_headline: Foundry Is Closing; Degas Debate Goes On
headline.main: Brass Foundry Is Closing, but Debate Over Degas’s Work Goes On

snippet: The Valsuani foundry, near Paris, has been ordered to liquidate, again bringing attention to whether liberties have been taken with the Degas bronzes it has issued.
lead_paragraph: The Valsuani foundry, near Paris, has been ordered to liquidate, again bringing attention to whether liberties have been taken with the Degas bronzes it has issued.
